messages.content: ComfyUI-TTS is a tool that allows you to convert strings within ComfyUI to audio so you can hear what's written. It's meant to be used with LLM AI models and is designed to be simple and easy.
What is the main objective of making ComfyUI-TTS?
The main objective of making ComfyUI-TTS was to integrate text generation and image generation AI in one interface and to see what other people can come up with to use them.
TTS stands for text to speech, which converts the written word to sound you can hear.
What are the upcoming features of ComfyUI-TTS?
Upcoming features include expanding the Piper-tts function options, implementing basic XTTSv2, and improving the functionality and usability of the program.
What do I need to install ComfyUI-TTS?

To install ComfyUI-TTS, you need Python and ComfyUI installed on your system. It is highly recommended to use ComfyUI-Manager to install the custom nodes, and you will also need to copy your ONNX and JSON files into the correct folder.
What is the purpose of JSON files in ComfyUI-TTS?
JSON files should be named the same as the ONNX files with a .json extension and contain additional information needed for the TTS program to function properly.
What should I do if I encounter installation or usage errors with ComfyUI-TTS?
If you encounter errors with installation or usage, either post an issue on the GitHub page or ask for help in the ComfyUI channel on Element.
What are the basic steps to use ComfyUI-TTS?

The basic steps to use ComfyUI-TTS include downloading and placing ONNX and JSON models in the correct folder, restarting ComfyUI, refreshing the browser, and then using the TTS nodes to generate audio from text.
What is an example of using ComfyUI-TTS?
An example of using ComfyUI-TTS can be found in the documentation with an image showing the node layout and connections for generating audio from text.
